doc.title: J.P.Morgan
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/FXO Event Risk Payrolls event premium nudged higher but overall event risk pricing remains light EUR vol curve now inver_2025-08-29

passages.text: Payrolls event premium nudged higher but overall event risk pricing remains light. EUR vol curve now inverted

Markets focus on US Payrolls, seen in a nudge higher in event risk premium. Although, from a historical view, current risk pricing is benign. EUR vol curve has inverted amid uncertainty around the French confidence vote and the potential subsequent developments but the lack of clarity on the overall timing of the process hampers further gains in event risk premium. Efficiently hedge the risk by buying 6M EUR/USD - EUR/PLN vol RV or get an exposure via EUR/USD 30d put vs sell EUR/PLN put (ie own EUR/USD risk- off and away from EUR/CEE skewness). x- leg should be better behaved either way, but mitigates the decay in event of a swift resolution. Favorably, the long USD leg participates in the US centric noise.

The focus on payrolls has intensified since the downside surprise in the August print. Event risk pricing is now packing in a higher premium than CPI and FOMC (Figure 1). The upcoming confidence vote for the French PM on Sept 8th is another event risk that is starting to attract attention, at least in the narratives, although remains modestly priced, with an average of 35bps for EUR/G10 (Figure 2) and close to 42bps for EUR/USD, amid the tendency to hedge the risk via EUR rather than on the crosses. If not for the timing uncertainty of potential outcomes following the vote which muddies the event risk pricing, the dayweight would probably be able to get to 55- 60bps breakevens (14vols, ie 3- 4 higher from here).
Figure 1: Relatively stronger focus on payrolls comes as no surprise considering the Aug print downside surprise.
Source: J.P. Morgan.
Figure 2: Sep 8th confidence vote relatively modest pricing reflects timing uncertainty of what may follow the vote.
Source: J.P. Morgan.

The heightened attention to jobs backdrop is reflected in the payrolls event risk premium, which saw an increase post- August and again as payrolls now approach within a week (Figure 3). Despite this uptick, the event risk premium remains relatively benign when compared to historical levels (Figure 6). Even so, it fares better than the CPI and FOMC event risk premiums, both of which are nearing their cycle lows (Figure 7 and Figure 8).

The shift in market focus towards the jobs backdrop has led to a gradual narrowing of the CPI event risk premium (Figure 4), while the FOMC event risk premium has modestly declined over the past week with this decline attributed to the stabilizing market expectations, with a 25bps cut in September now fairly anchored post- Powell's remarks (Figure 5).

Figure 3: Payrolls event risk premium (calculated as event risk / normalized vol) got a bump post Aug print and then again this week. Normalized vol = Sep \(30^{\text{th}}\) spot vol (stripped of the event risk premiums).
Source: J.P. Morgan.
Figure 5: FOMC event risk premium modestly declined in the last 7 days as markets expectations steadied.
Source: J.P. Morgan.

Figure 6: Even following the recent uptick in the pricing, the payrolls event risk premium remains benign relative to the historicals ... Event risk premium = daily volume of base vols (aka normalized daily vols)
Source: J.P. Morgan.
Figure 4: With the immediate market focus shifting to jobs backdrop CPI event risk premium gradually narrowed.
Source: J.P. Morgan.
Figure 7: ... but at least faring better than CPI and ...
Source: J.P. Morgan.
Figure 8: ... FOMC both of which are near their cycle lows. G10 FOMC Event Premiums Leading Tighter in December FOMC
Source: J.P. Morgan.

The modest market's pricing of these event risks highlights a lingering degree of complacency, reminiscent of the light pricing ahead of Powell's Jackson Hole speech. Back then, the pricing fell short of the subsequent price action, which was amplified by low liquidity. Liquidity should not be an issue in September, but the pricing leaves little room for surprises. Looking at the aggregate event risk premium baked into USD/FX (Figure 9) turns out that pricing is relatively more concentrated into European G10 currencies vols, with EM and Antipodeans lagging. That said, we discuss below EUR/USD RVs that still allow for efficient exposure of EUR/USD exposure.
Figure 9: Sep event risk (in aggregate) is relatively more concentrated into European G10 currencies vols.
Source: J.P. Morgan.

While recent developments such as the French confidence vote and the upcoming UK budget have shifted some focus away from the US, we think that keeping the long USD correlations is still the right view.

That keeps us interested in long USD vols vs short x- vols RV. The renewed interest in EUR vol inverted the curve although the probability of tail outcomes (a left government or Macron's resignation) remains low (see the detailed discussion here). The uncertainty in the timeline following a potential no- confidence vote makes it challenging for market
makers to reflect the risk in daily vols, as seen in the EUR vol curve inversion, rather than premium built up in a specific dayweight, which indicates a spread- out premium amid hedging flows.

Interestingly, a long- term backtest reveals a shift in performance, with long EUR/USD vs. EUR/FX vol RVs showing robust positive performance, outpacing the USD/FX - EUR/FX vol spreads since 2022. The 4M- 6M tenor strikes a good compromise in mitigating the EUR/USD vol curve inversion, offering participation in the near term developments, but also exposure to potential snap elections.

Vol RVs, such as long EUR/USD vs. short EUR/PLN, are economical as the European backdrop should anchor the EUR/CEE leg more than the EUR/USD leg. In the event of a quick resolution and normalization, the re- steepening of the EUR/USD vol curve, EUR/CEE leg should provide some cushion. Given its cleaner positioning backdrop, PLN is a better choice than HUF. We recommend:
— 6M long EUR/USD straddle @7.35ch vs. short EUR/PLN straddle @4.75/4.95 indic, delta- hedged, equal vega.
Figure 10: The pace of returns for EURxEM pairs has outperformed the USD counterparts since 2022.

Alternatively, one can leverage the skew setup (to own EUR/USD risk- off and away from EUR/CEE) by buying exposure through an RV of type: long 6M EUR/USD 30d put, financed by selling an EUR/PLN 30d put:
— Buy EUR/USD 30d put @7.26ch vs sell EUR/PLN 30d put @4.55/4.75 indic, at net cost of 37/42bps, same EUR notional.
